@pegobry You'll see the same thing for any major domain name, e.g. whois microsoft.com -- it's harmless.
@pegobry You're misunderstanding the whois output; that just means other people named their server apple.com -- the real thing is untouched.
@aaronsw For example, whois microsoft.com will get you the same silliness (and more).
@felixsalmon Those are unrelated DNS servers named apple.com.was. and so on -- do "whois =apple.com" to see the real Apple.com record.
@felixsalmon People distributing that don't know how WHOIS works; that's perfectly normal, not a hack.
@chpwn No, it's awesome! You've got the power!
I just got retweeted by @chpwn and now 3 people are retweeting me every second. This is insane.
